basan decision Theory and it's more

how the brain deals with uncertainty and
the fundamental idea is you want to make

let's think about the inference you want

what are beliefs beliefs could be where

we're going to represent a belief with a

I do not believe it at all one means I'm
absolutely certain and numbers in
between give you the gray levels of
uncertainty and the key idea to beian
inference is you have two sources of
information from which to make your
inference you have data and data in
Neuroscience is sensory input so I have
sensory input which I can take into make
beliefs but there's another source of
information and that's effectively prior
knowledge you accumulate knowledge
throughout your life in memories and the
point about be and decision theory is it
gives you the mathematics of the optimal
way to combine your prior knowledge with
sensory evidence to generate new beliefs
and I put the formula up there I'm not
going to explain to you what that formul
is but it's very beautiful and it has
real Beauty and real explanatory power
and what it really says is what you want
to estimate is the probability of
different beliefs given your sensory
input so let me give you an intuitive

there are two sources of information Bay
rule tells you there's sensory evidence
you can use visual information auditory

that your senses are not perfect and
therefore there's some variability in
where it's going to land shown by that
cloud of red representing numbers
between .5 and maybe 0.1 that
information is available on the current

information not available on the current

that's that the ball doesn't bounce with

a match if you're playing against a very

that green area which is the prior
distribution making it hard for you to
return now both these sources of
information carry important information
and what beasal says is I should

and that's my belief
so it's the optimal way of combining
information now I wouldn't tell you all

we show this is exactly what people do
